A 22-day-old baby presenting with seizures, increased head size over the past week, and a sunset sign in the eyes, what is the most common cause of this condition?

A 45-year-old patient was brought in with complaints of postural instability. Post examination, you confirm that it has nothing to do with vertigo and suspect it could be of cerebellar origin. Which of the following symptoms cannot be seen in cerebellar lesions?

A 40-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, double vision, the eyeball was looking down and out, the pupil dilated, and drooping eyelid over the last 2 hours. MRI angiography shows an aneurysm of a cerebral artery. Which artery gives rise to the aneurysm?

A 44-year-old female was brought unconscious to the emergency room by the Police, after reportedly being shot. She was pale, and her abdomen was tight and swollen. Emergency laparotomy revealed severe damage to the portal vein causing blood loss from all its following tributaries, except?
The tendon of which of the following muscles will be involved in a fracture of the posterior surface of the talus bone?
questions.explanation:
Tendons of muscles of foot

                 Location and attachments

Flexor digitorum longus
  • Its tendon goes behind the medial malleolus and enters the sole in its medial sides.

Flexor digitorum brevis
  • It lies inferior to the tendon of the flexor digitorum longus.

Flexor hallucis brevis
  • Flexor hallucis brevis is composed of medial and lateral muscle bellies whose tendon attach at the proximal phalanx of the great toe.

Flexor hallucis longus
  • Lies in the first groove on the posterior surface of the talus bone and then the groove on the lower surface of the sustentaculum tali.

Which of the following is affected by this infection apart from the bulbourethral glands?

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was undergoing surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck. The surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery during the surgery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He denies any fever or previous respiratory complaints. After making an appropriate diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning, treatment with hyperbaric oxygen therapy is initiated. The treatment increases arterial PO2 to 2000 mm Hg. Which of the following is the amount of dissolved oxygen in arterial blood (in ml / 100 ml)?
questions.explanation:
Parameters

Formulas/ Equations

O2 content

(O2 bound to Hemoglobin) + (O2 solubilized in plasma) = (1.34 × Hb × SaO2) + (0.003 × PaO2)

Solubility of Oxygen

0.003 ml O2 / 100 ml blood

O2 delivery to tissues

cardiac output × O2 content of blood

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has a GFR of 100 ml/min, her urine flow rate is 2.0 ml/min, and her plasma glucose concentration is 200 mg/100 ml. If the kidney transport maximum for glucose is 250 mg/min, what would be her approximate rate of glucose excretion?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ The filtration rate of glucose in this example is: = GFR × Plasma glucose concentration = (100 ml/min) × (200 mg/100 ml, or 2 mg/ml) = 200 mg/min.
  • ➤ The filtration rate of glucose in this example is: = GFR × Plasma glucose concentration = (100 ml/min) × (200 mg/100 ml, or 2 mg/ml) = 200 mg/min.
  • ➤ The filtration rate of glucose in this example is: = GFR × Plasma glucose concentration = (100 ml/min) × (200 mg/100 ml, or 2 mg/ml) = 200 mg/min.
  • ➤ The filtration rate of glucose in this example is:
  • ➤ The filtration rate of glucose in this example is:
  • ➤ = GFR × Plasma glucose concentration
  • ➤ = (100 ml/min) × (200 mg/100 ml, or 2 mg/ml)
  • ➤ Because the transport maximum for glucose in this example is 250 mg/min, All of the filtered glucose would be reabsorbed and the renal excretion rate for glucose would be zero(0 mg/min). Glucose appears in urine when the blood glucose level increases above 180 mg/dL. Glycosuria (presence of glucose in urine) may be the first indicator of diabetes mellitus.

  • ➤ Glucose appears in urine when the blood glucose level increases above 180 mg/dL. Glycosuria (presence of glucose in urine) may be the first indicator of diabetes mellitus.
  • ➤ Absorption of Glucose
  • ➤ Absorption of Glucose
  • ➤ Glucose is transported from the lumen of small intestine into the epithelial cells in the mucus membrane of small intestine, by means of sodium cotransport. Energy for this is obtained by the binding process of sodium ion and glucose molecule to carrier protein. From the epithelial cell, glucose is absorbed into the portal vein by facilitated diffusion. However, sodium ion moves laterally into the intercellular space. From here, it is transported into blood by active transport, utilizing the energy liberated by breakdown of ATP. Tubular maximum for glucose (TmG) : In adult male, TmG is 375 mg/minute and in adult females it about 300 mg/minute. The renal threshold for glucose: Renal threshold for glucose is 180 mg/dL in venous blood. When the blood level reaches 180 mg/dL glucose is not reabsorbed completely and appears in urine.

questions.text: RIA is very sensitive in vitro assay technique used to measure concentrations of substances, usually measuring antigen concentrations (for example, hormone levels in the blood) by use of antibodies. If a radioimmunoassay is properly conducted and the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, what would this result indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high

options.label: B
options.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are low

questions.correct_answer: A. Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation with ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration sense ?

The relation between intravesical pressure and volume can be studied by inserting a catheter, emptying the bladder, and then recording the pressure. At the same time, the bladder is filled with 50-mL increments of water or air (cytometry). A plot of intravesical pressure against the fluid volume in the bladder is called a Cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at which of the following point?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Cystometry refers to the process of studying the relationship between the intravesical volume and pressure, the Cystometrogram refers to a graphical record of this relationship. Normal cystometrogram shows three phases of filling: Phase Ia: It is the initial phase of filling in which pressure rises from 0 to 10 cm H 2 O when about 50 mL of fluid is collected in the bladder. Phase Ib: It is the phase of the plateau which lasts till the bladder volume is 400 mL. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400mL. The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace. Phase II: This phase starts beyond 400 mL volume when the pressure begins to rise markedly triggering the micturition reflex.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with type I (DM) diabetes went to an ophthalmologist for assessment of developing a cataract. The results of his blood work are shown below: Fasting blood glucose 180 gm/dl Hemoglobin A 15 mg/dl Hemoglobin A1c 10% of total Hb Urine ketones Positive Urine glucose Positive Which of the following enzymes is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?

A patient presents with yellowish eyes and skin. He also has itching, pain in the upper right side of the abdomen, and weight loss. Laboratory analysis of urine bilirubin indicates obstructive jaundice. The test of which of the following enzyme will substantiate these findings?

A newborn is tested for phenylketonuria (PKU) using a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord . Based on the blood report, the newborn is declared negative for PKU, and the pediatrician imposes no dietary restrictions. The child is again brought to the pediatrician after 12 months . This time, the child is reported to have aggressive behavior and delayed milestones . Blood and urine tests for PKU are redone, and they are positive this time. Finally, a diagnosis of PKU is made. What is the most probable reason for misdiagnosis at birth in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood

options.label: B
options.text: The Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal blood should have been used

options.label: D
options.text: The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.correct_answer: D. The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the lipid profile will most probably confirm the diagnosis of Tangier's disease ?
questions.correct_answer: A. Low or absence of HDL

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to a pediatrician with complaints of muscle pain and weakness . Further investigations revealed hepatomegaly and cardiomegaly . Liver biopsy analysis showed nonspecific fatty changes and a muscle biopsy revealed large amounts of cytoplasmic vacuoles containing neutral lipids . Additionally, during a one-day fast, the child experienced hypoglycemia with a normal blood pH and the absence of ketone bodies. What is the most likely cause of these findings ?

A 3-year-old boy is being evaluated for developmental delay and poor muscle control. The parents are concerned since the child has started to bite his lips and fingers . Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of serum uric acid. Which of the following specific reactions is not catalyzed in the suspected diagnosis?
A 25 year old female patient is brought to the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of a panic attack. Which of the following arterial blood pHs would be most consistent with her diagnosis?

RFLP analysis using site flanking the ApoB100 gene on chromosome 2 among members of a family with a history of Hypercholesterolemia yielded one large fragment and one smaller fragment that is also seen in controls. What is the probable inheritance mechanism in this family?

A sixty-nine-year-old male presented to your clinic with complaints of tremors, stiffness of his limbs and a change in his gait. He also complains of having difficulty initiating movements. He says these symptoms have been slowly progressing and have made it difficult for him to perform his daily activities. Investigations are performed, and a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease is made. During increased cellular stress, the energy-depleted cell eats its cellular components to compensate for nutrient depletion. Which of the following is a good marker to look for in cells to detect this process?

An 83-year-old thin-built male is presented to the emergency department by her son. She is unconscious. Upon examination, Pulse was feeble, BP unrecordable, and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was 3/15. ECG showed a Flatline in all leads. An autopsy was done. Histopathologic examination of cardiac tissue revealed peri-nuclear brown pigment. This finding occurs due to which reason?

You’re an intern in dermatology OPD. The dermatology resident on OPD firmly strokes the skin of a patient, which initially produces a red line followed by a flare around that line and then finally a wheel. The following response is caused due to ?
questions.explanation:
Lewis’s triple response
  • When histamine is injected intradermally, it causes a triple response:
    • Red spot: Because of capillary dilatation.
    • Wheal: Due to the exudation of fluid from capillaries and venules.
    • Flare: Redness in the surrounding area is due to arteriolar dilation mediated by axon reflex.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with a history of recurrent bacterial infections presents with a fever and a productive cough. Biochemical analysis of his neutrophils shows the problem in an oxidative burst. This patient most likely has inherited a mutation in the gene that encodes which of the following proteins?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Defect

Defects in Leukocyte Function

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in β chain of CDI 1/CDI 8 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in fucosyl transferase required for synthesis of sailylated oligosaccharide (receptor for selectins)

Chediak-Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte function because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic

Chronic granulomatous disease

X-linked

Autosomal recessive

Decreased oxidative burst

Phagocyte oxidase (membrane component)

Phagocyte oxidase (cytoplasmic components)

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

Defects in the Complement System

C2, C4 deficiency

Defective classical pathway activation results in reduced resistance to infection and reduced clearance of immune complexes

C3 deficiency

Defects in all complement functions

Deficiency of complement regulatory proteins

Excessive complement activation; clinical syndromes include angioedema, paroxysmal hemoglobinuria, others

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing. He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. The remaining immunoglobulin IgE, IgM, and IgG were within normal limits. Which of the following is the most important risk about the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

questions.correct_answer: D. Anaphylactic reaction on blood transfusion
questions.explanation:
Selective IgA deficiency
  • Most common primary immunodeficiency with low IgA and normal IgG, IgM levels.
  • Patients are susceptible to respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, atopy and anaphylaxis to IgA in blood products.
  • Patients develop IgE antibodies against the IgA antibodies present in transfused blood.
  • This sensitization can result in susceptibility to anaphylaxis on subsequent transfusion.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presented to an outpatient clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing. He has a history of IV drug abuse. An examination of his oral cavity revealed that most of his tongue and palate are covered in yellowish membranes. Several white, ulcerated lesions in the oesophagus are also discovered during endoscopy. The primary cause of these pathologic findings in this patient is the loss of which of the following immune cells?

A 30-year-old female presents in an anxious state to the Pediatric department complaining that her 2-year-old male child has intellectual disabilities, kinky and tangled hair, pudgy rosy cheeks with sagging facial skin since birth. She is hesitant about her children having kinky hair disease because her two sisters who had sons died from kinky hair disease. Her mother's elder brother also died of the same disorder. Which of the following could be the possible mode of inheritance in her family?

A 10-year-old black girl is brought to the emergency department complaining of severe painful swelling in her hands and feet from the last week and pallor of the conjunctiva, fatigue, and weakness from the last two weeks. Some family members had a history of the same symptoms. Physical examination shows yellowing of eyes, skin, conjunctiva pallor, and swelling in hands and feet. A Complete blood count reveals normocytic anaemia with marked poikilocytosis. A peripheral blood film is shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely finding on haemoglobin electrophoresis?

options.label: B
options.text: Increase HbA2, HbS, and HbF and Decrease HbA

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase HbA2, HbS, and HbF and Decrease HbA

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman reports fatigue and hematuria. Physical examination reveals significant pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and numerous upper and lower extremities ecchymoses. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals normocytic normochromic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, and a significant leukocytosis composed primarily of myeloblasts. Which of the following is the most directly related to the major clinical problems associated with this patient's condition?

A 50-year-old man presented to medical OPD with a pruritic rash that had been bothering him for several years. The rash was first scaly, erythematous, eczematoid patches distributed asymmetrically over his chest and abdomen. It later changed to hard and raised plaques. The plaque biopsy was done, which revealed atypical CD4+T cells with cerebriform nuclei. Which of the following statements about this disease is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease eventually disseminates to lymph nodes and internal organs

options.label: B
options.text: The neoplastic cells most commonly display cell markers of CD19 and CD20

options.label: C
options.text: The skin rash most commonly disappears over time

options.label: D
options.text: This disease is caused by chronic fungal infection in the skin

Which diagnostic procedures would be most useful in evaluating the possibility that pheochromocytoma might cause these findings?

A 26-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology outpatient department for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no presenting complaints, and her menstrual cycles are regular. A Pap smear is performed, and the examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever . Physical examination reveals signs of jaundice . He has no history of pancreatitis or any alcohol or drug abuse . His vitals show mild tachycardia with normal blood pressure. Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis, normal haemoglobin, increased direct bilirubin, normal serum indirect bilirubin, and increased alkaline phosphatase . He was prescribed oxybutynin but experienced dry mouth and increased water intake despite fearing excessive urination. What action does the drug in this scenario take to treat overactive bladder?

A 32-year-old female presents with frequent headaches, palpitations, and nausea for the last 2 weeks. She has gestational amenorrhea of 4 weeks. She has a blood pressure of 150/90mmHg. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is not safe for gestational hypertension?

A 44-year-old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. The patient sought a consultation since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you noticed that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, random blood sugar, and an ultrasound of kidney, ureters, and, bladder (KUB), all of which turn out to be normal . Urinary and serum osmolality is consistent with diabetes insipidus . What would be the rationale for opting intranasal desmopressin spray over vasopressin?

options.label: C
options.text: It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype

options.text: Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

Similarities

questions.explanation:
Microorganism Pneumocystis jirovecii
Classification Fungus (formerly classified as a protozoan)
Infection Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), an opportunistic infection affecting the lungs in immunocompromised individuals
Transmission Likely via airborne route
Predisposing Factors - HIV/AIDS- Organ transplantation- Immunosuppressive therapy- Certain malignancies
Clinical Presentation - Dry cough
- Shortness of breath
- Fever
- Chest discomfort
Diagnosis - Chest X-ray or CT scan- Microscopic examination of respiratory specimens- PCR testing
Treatment Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the primary treatment
Prophylaxis Recommended for individuals at high risk (e.g., HIV patients with low CD4 counts)
Prevention - Antiretroviral therapy for HIV/AIDS patients- Prophylactic antibiotics in high-risk patients
Epidemiology Common among immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS

questions.text: What is the incubation period of typhoid fever?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Age is the most important risk factor for breast cancer. Breast cancer is uncommon below age of 35, its incidence is increasing rapidly b/w ages of 35 to 50. A slight bimodal trend in the age distribution has been observed with a dip in incidence at the time of menopause. A secondary rise in frequency often occurs after the age of 65. Women who developed their first breast cancer under the age of 40, had three times the risk of developing a second breast cancer than those who developed their first cancer after the age of 40 Indeed the etiologies of pre-menopausal & post-menopausal breast cancer appears to be different. Other Risk factors of breast cancer: Family history of breast cancer Delayed first pregnancy Early menarche and late menopause Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels Prior breast biopsy Higher socio-economic status Radiation exposure etc.

  • ➤ Breast cancer is uncommon below age of 35, its incidence is increasing rapidly b/w ages of 35 to 50.
  • ➤ A slight bimodal trend in the age distribution has been observed with a dip in incidence at the time of menopause.
  • ➤ A secondary rise in frequency often occurs after the age of 65. Women who developed their first breast cancer under the age of 40, had three times the risk of developing a second breast cancer than those who developed their first cancer after the age of 40 Indeed the etiologies of pre-menopausal & post-menopausal breast cancer appears to be different.
  • ➤ Other Risk factors of breast cancer: Family history of breast cancer Delayed first pregnancy Early menarche and late menopause Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels Prior breast biopsy Higher socio-economic status Radiation exposure etc.
  • ➤ Family history of breast cancer Delayed first pregnancy Early menarche and late menopause Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels Prior breast biopsy Higher socio-economic status Radiation exposure etc.

  • ➤ Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels
  • ➤ Prior breast biopsy
  • ➤ Higher socio-economic status
  • ➤ Radiation exposure etc.
    • Name of the Disease Typhoid Fever Causative Agent Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi (S. Typhi) Transmission Usually transmitted through contaminated food or water, rarely person-to-person contact Incubation Period Typically 6 to 30 days after exposure Common Symptoms High fever, abdominal pain, headache, weakness, and diarrhea. Rash may also occur. Severity Typhoid fever can range from mild to severe; untreated cases can be life-threatening. Diagnosis Blood, stool, or urine culture to isolate S. Typhi. Blood tests for antibodies or antigens. Treatment Antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin or azithromycin. Adequate hydration and rest are crucial. Vaccination Vaccines like Typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) or Ty21a oral vaccine are available for prevention. Prevention Good hygiene, safe food and water practices, and vaccination are key preventive measures. Epidemiology Common in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene practices. Occurs worldwide but more prevalent in some regions. Complications Intestinal perforation, sepsis, and other serious complications can occur if untreated. Quarantine Measures Isolation precautions are not typically required, but infected individuals should avoid preparing or handling food.

The patient has a history of pain in small joint hands as well, nearly all the time, unaffected by the use of joints. He remembers his father used to have the same symptoms in old age. An X-ray of the foot was done, which showed lytic punched-out lesions. Identify the disease and the sign associated with it.

An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with multiple episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizure for the last 10 days. On general examination, he has multiple hyper-pigmented papules over the nasolabial region and cheeks, multiple hypo-pigmented macules over the lower limbs and a Shagreen patch over the lateral aspect of the right buttock. A diagnosis of Tuberous Sclerosis is suspected . Which of the following findings in his computed tomography (CT) scan is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Major features of TSC

Minor features of TSC
  • Facial angiofibroma’s or forehead plaque
  • Non-traumatic ungual or periungual fibroma
  • Hypomelanotic macules (>3)
  • Shagreen patch
  • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
  • Cortical tuber
  • Subependymal nodule
  • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma, single or multiple
  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipomas
  • Multiple randomly distributed pits in dental enamel
  • Hamartomatous rectal polyps
  • Bone Cysts
  • Cerebral white matter radial migration lines
  • Gingival fibromas
  • Retinal achromic patch
  • "Confetti" skin lesions
  • Multiple renal cysts

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was found to have clinical features of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia(CML) on a peripheral blood smear. On detailed evaluation, the patient also had a T315I mutation in BCR-ABL. What is the first-line treatment for this patient?

33 years male presented to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, there is mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation over the lips. Histopathological examination showed arborisation and pseudo invasion. Genetic analysis revealed that the gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Drug of choice in Dermatitis herpetiformis?

A 25-year-old female complained of difficulty swallowing solids and liquids for the past 6 months associated with regurgitation of food. She has lost 4kg(9 lb) during this period. There is no history of serious illness. She is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. Cardiopulmonary examination shows an S3 gallop and a systolic murmur. On barium swallow, characteristic appearance is seen on X-ray as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most common complication in this condition?

A 60-year-old patient is being monitored in a coronary care unit for two days following myocardial infarction. Revascularization was done by primary percutaneous intervention . During monitoring, an ECG is done, which shows the following rhythm: His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg , and his pulse is 27 per minute . Which of the following is best for the management of this patient?

A 50-year-old male patient has come to the hospital to undergo dialysis . His Hb was 5.5 mg/dl at the time of admission . Three units of blood transfusions were given as a part of resuscitation. After the third blood transfusion, within 8 hours, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension, SpO2 was reduced to 65%, CVP was 16cm water, and PCWP was 26mm Hg . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of the right-side face, arm weakness, and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 76 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words . He can follow simple instructions . Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 3/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left . Non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?

A 64-year-old male unconscious patient was brought to the emergency department with a high-grade fever . The attendee recalls a history of double vision, dysphagia, and unsteady gait in the patient. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension for the past 13 years, well controlled by anti-hypertensives. On examination, his temperature was 102.8 degrees Fahrenheit, and his pupils were bilaterally pinpoint . What of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A woman comes to psychiatrist with a history of spending a lot of time washing her hands. She is distressed about it but says that she is not able to stop washing. This has started to affect her social life as well. What is the best mode of treatment for her?

A 22-year-old female is brought by her family members with complaints of low weight. According to the mother, the patient is extremely picky about what she eats, and the amount of food taken is quite low compared to others. In the interview, the patient says that she doesn't feel like eating, and although she realizes that she is losing weight which is not good, she just can't eat more. No body image disturbances are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Avoidant - restrictive food intake disorder

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the psychiatrist by his parents with complaints of not following the rules of the school and arguing with teachers and fellow students. The parents report that he misbehaves with them too and at times tries to provoke them. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Oppositional defiance disorder (ODD) is defined as a recurrent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behavior towards authority figures. It is one of the most common psychiatric disorders of childhood, and whilst a risk factor for the more serious conduct disorder, the majority do not progress to more serious psychopathology or psychopathy.

Conduct disorder can be considered a more severe form of the oppositional defiant disorder. The child also shows symptoms that are direct violation of the rights of others and societal rules and norms are broken.

  • Bullying or hitting other children.
  • Stealing
  • Putting things on fire.
  • Cruelty towards animals
  • Frequent lying
  • Running away from the house

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient department due to a psychiatric disorder. She has had persistent symptoms for the past 9 months. Her symptoms have not improved with 5 trials of medications. The clinician suggests the brain stimulation method (shown below) for her: The brain stimulation method is used for which of the following diseases?

A 54-year-old female diagnosed with bipolar disorder and on treatment for 6 years came to your clinic with complaints of greenish nipple discharge associated with pain in both breasts. A physical examination revealed bilateral nipple retraction with little nipple discharge. Histopathology revealed dilated ducts in both breasts. Which is the best step in managing this patient’s underlying breast condition?

A 22-day-old girl is brought to the outpatient department due to persistent jaundice after birth. 10 days ago, her parents noticed yellow discoloration of her eyes and skin that has been progressively increasing for the last 3 days. She was born to a 24-year-old primigravida woman via normal vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was unremarkable. Further query reveals that her stools are pale in color. The patient is breastfed exclusively and has been feeding well. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 26/min. Capillary refill is <2 seconds. Examination reveals a diffusely jaundiced infant. Abdominal examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen with hepatomegaly. The metabolic screen is normal, ultrasound demonstrates an absent gallbladder, and a technetium-99m iminodiacetic acid scan shows radionuclide that is concentrated in the liver but not excreted into the intestine . Which of the following is true regarding the presentation of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: This condition is usually managed non-operatively.

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery should be performed within 60 days of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Most of these patients will not require transplantation if left untreated.

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgery should be performed within 60 days of life.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after sustaining a blow to the right side of his head when his motorcycle slid on gravel and flipped on the side of the road. After the accident, the patient noted burning pain in his neck. On examination, complete quadriplegia is noted with a sensory level at C4.The patient has not passed urine since then, and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The doctor should order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient should not be shifted and a portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

options.label: C
options.text: The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray-AP and lateral view without any cervical support

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient should not be shifted and a portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with complaints of dyspnea. He is a lifetime smoker. His pulse is 99/min, and his blood pressure is 95/66 mmHg. Examination shows swelling and redness of the face and neck. There is distention of the superficial veins of his neck and upper thorax. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest x-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step in establishing a diagnosis for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to the hospital feeling unwell for the previous few weeks, mainly complaining of muscle weakness. He denied any fevers or rigors and any change in bowel habits or vomiting. He did not report any memory or mood problems. Physical examination was remarkable for profound lethargy but otherwise, he was fully orientated, stable hemodynamically, without any significant clinical signs, including no focal neurological deficit. Blood tests on admission were remarkable for severe metabolic acidosis (pH 7.20, HCO 3 11.3, base excess −17 with normal lactate of 1). From the given data all of the following can be considered as a differential diagnosis for this patient except?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ In this question, the patient has a severe metabolic acidosis. Options must be the reason for that metabolic acidosis to consider it as the differential diagnosis of this patient. Options like renal failure, ureterosigmoidostomy, and pancreatic or biliary fistula can cause metabolic acidosis. But hypertrophic pyloric stenosis causes hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. So it is the odd one out to choose. we must know which conditions can cause metabolic acidosis and alkalosis.

CAUSES OF NON-ANION GAP ACIDOSIS

Mnemonic- USED CARP

U-Ureteraldiversion

S-Small Bowel Fistula

E-Extra Chloride (ammonium chloride, Calcium Chloride)

D-Diarrhea

C-Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Acetazolamide, Mefenamic acid)

A-Adrenal Insufficiency

R-Renal Tubular Acidosis

P-Pancreatic Fistula

CAUSES OF HIGH ANION GAP ACIDOSIS

Mnemonic- MUD PILERS

M Methanol, Metformin

U Uremia

D Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), Alcoholic Ketoacidosis or Starvation Ketosis

P Paraldehyde, Phenformin

I Iron, Isopropyl Alcohol, and Isoniazid (due to Seizures)

L Lactic Acidosis

E Ethylene Glycol, Ethyl Alcohol

R Rhabdomyolysis

S Salicylates (do not miss Chronic Salicylate Poisoning)

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for the survival of the skin graft within 48 hours of the grafting?

A 47-year-old male patient is brought to the c linic complaining of a large erythematous skin pocket on his sacrum and left hip . He has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, diagnosed two years ago . Examination reveals large 3-4 cm pressure sores , as shown in the image below. Which would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery is the only modality of the treatment

options.label: B
options.text: A fasciocutaneous flap should be used

options.label: C
options.text: Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies.

options.label: D
options.text: Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

questions.correct_answer: D. Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with the complaint of progressively worsening ulcers in the fingertips of both hands and feet for 4 years, along with intermittent claudication of the feet whenever he is walking. After taking history, he told the doctor that he had "migratory superficial thrombophlebitis." He is a 20-pack-year smoker who is not a diabetic; his cholesterol levels are normal according to him, and his ECG findings were normal. What would be the best way for this patient to arrest the development of his disease?

A 25-year old male presents to ER following a road traffic accident sustaining injuries to the lower abdomen. On examination, there is a pelvic hematoma and fracture . Physical examination shows a palpable bladder, and blood at the external urethral meatus . A digital rectal examination shows impalpable prostate . On the basis of examination, which of the following is true about the patient's diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior urethra is the most likely place of injury

options.label: B
options.text: Retrograde urethrography should be done immediately

options.label: C
options.text: A Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal

options.label: D
options.text: Rectal examination may not reveal a large pelvic hematoma

questions.correct_answer: C. A Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency departmentwith a complaint of blood in urine for last one hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/60mmHg, pulse rate is 110/minute, and fullness in his left loin. On history, he reports that on the same day in the morning, he played rugby. After that, he passed frank blood in his urine. He also feels mild discomfort in his left loin. What is the diagnosis related to the above-mentioned patient's condition?

A 15-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of bruises all over the body and frequent episodes of bleeding from the gum and nose . Upon examination, she had multiple petechiae all over her body. Investigation shows isolated thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 8000/mm3 and red blood cells in urine examination, suggesting hematuria . All other diagnostic evaluations are normal. A splenectomy was done in this patient to tide over the acute crisis of uncontrollable:

A 60-year-old male is diagnosed with a carcinoma stomach. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass measuring 4x4 cm in the antrum. The mass indicates celiac node and right gastric node involvement. Which of the following is the preferred management option?
questions.explanation:
Type Amount of stomach removed
Total gastrectomy Entire stomach
Near Total gastrectomy >90%
Sub-total gastrectomy 80% - 90%
Partial gastrectomy 65% - 75%
Hemi gastrectomy 50%
Antrectomy (distal gastrectomy) 35% - 50%

questions.text: Which of the following best associates with the clinical condition that includes abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal pain, and growth of E. coli on the ascitic fluid culture medium of a patient with cirrhosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple organisms are isolated from ascitic fluid

options.label: D
options.text: 3rd Generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

questions.correct_answer: D. 3rd Generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a family history of hyperparathyroidism was brought to the OPD with complaints of loin pain . On evaluation, multiple renal calculi were noted in both kidneys . Serum calcium, PTH, and prolactin are elevated. Which of the following organs was most likely affected first in this patient?

A 37-year-old Indian man who had recently moved to Taiwan presented with right upper quadrant pain and intermittent low-grade fever . Both sonography and computed tomography demonstrated a cystic lesion with vesicles at its periphery in segments 6 and 7 of the liver . What is your probable diagnosis?

A 67-year-old man with acute pancreatitis complaints of recurrent episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemoglobin of 5.8 gm/dL, requiring transfusions of red cell units. Gastroscopy showed diffuse fundal gastric varices but no esophageal varices. A CT scan showed liquefactive necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma and splenomegaly with diffuse varices around the gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligament . Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment?

A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department after he sustained a burn injury to his right arm when his hand was trapped in a steam-rolling machine for making carpets under high temperatures. He has severe burn in his right arm. On examination, a third-degree circumferential burn wound is noted in the right arm and forearm. Which of the following has to be closely monitored in this patient?

A 62-year-old man presents to the OPD for an annual physical examination. After noting a PSA level of 12.3 ng/dL, you refer him to a urologist for further workup. Following a prostatic biopsy, the results show the presence of adenocarcinoma of the prostate, which is given a Gleason score of 8. The Gleason score is a measurement of:

options.label: A
options.text: The extent of cancer within the prostate gland

options.label: B
options.text: The extent of the cancer within the abdomen

options.label: C
options.text: The likelihood that the cancer will grow and spread

options.label: D
options.text: The number of cancer cells expressing prostate specific antigen (PSA) on their cell surface

questions.correct_answer: C. The likelihood that the cancer will grow and spread
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ Prostate biopsies involve the sampling of tissue from several different areas of the gland (normally at least six). Two samples that appear to be most heavily involved, then histologically graded on a scale from 1 to 5 numbers are combined to give a Gleason score of 2 to 10

questions.text: Mark the correct statement about gallstone illeus:

options.label: A
options.text: The most common fistula is cholecystocolic

options.label: B
options.text: Most common site of obstruction is jejunum

questions.correct_answer: D. Most commonly seen in elderly
questions.explanation:
Gallstone ileus
  • A mechanical blockage by a large gallstone erodes through the wall of the gallbladder directly into the intestine via a choledochoenteric fistula and this results in the air entering the biliary tree (pneumobilia).
  • Most commonly seen in elderly due to pressure necrosis.
  • Most common is choledochoduodenal fistula.
  • The second most common is cholecystocolic fistula
  • Obstruction is most commonly in the distal ileum, about 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve
  • Bouveret syndrome is gastric outlet obstruction caused by proximal stones impaction.
  • Exploration and enterotomy are required to relieve the obstruction

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the surgical outpatient department complaining of slowly progressive leg edema for three days. She gives no history of any other abnormalities. She has no history of any chronic illnesses. She is vitally stable. The patient's physical examination revealed non-pitting bilateral leg edema that does not improve with elevation . According to Brunner’s clinical classification of lymphedema, the patient’s pathology falls under which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Brunner’s clinical classification of Lymphedema
Grade Clinical features
Subclinical (latent) Excess interstitial fluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, no clinically apparent lymphedema.
I Pitting edema largely or completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.
II Non–pitting edema does not significantly reduce upon elevation.
III Edema associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. fibrosis papillae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of vomiting blood, abdominal distension , and yellowing of eyes. He has a ten-year history of drinking 1-3 bottles of wine daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice, palmar erythema, spider nevi on his chest, dilated veins on the anterior abdominal wall, and 2+ oedema of the lower extremities. The abdomen is soft and diffusely tender; there is shifting dullness to percussion. His albumin is 1.3 g/dL, bilirubin is 54.8mg/dL, and prothrombin time is 32 seconds (INR = 3.3). Hepatitis serology is negative. Which scoring system cannot be used to assess whether the patient is a suitable candidate for liver transplantation?
questions.correct_answer: D. Estimated Post Transplant Survival (EPTS) score

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the emergency department by paramedics after sustaining a road traffic accident 30 minutes ago. The patient is conscious and aware of his surroundings. He reports pain in his right shoulder. On physical examination, tenderness is found on the clavicle of the right side. He is unable to raise the right arm due to severe shoulder pain. The physician suspects a clavicular fracture. Which of the following site of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured?

You are a group of 6 medical students going to a weekend party in Goa. One of your friends' head hit a sandbank as he dived into the waves and was floating on the water for approximately 30 seconds. One of you realized he was having trouble and checked on him. All of you are experienced first aiders and were first responders to the accident. Upon initial examination, his pupils are equal and reactive to light. He showed no other signs of injury. He complain ed that he could not feel his arms and legs. You quickly diagnosed it as a case of spinal shock and took him to a nearby trauma center. Upon arrival, knowing that you all are medical students, the trauma surgeon asks you what is the first reflex to recover after spinal shock .

A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a swollen knee after getting hit over the lateral aspect of the knee two hours ago. On examination, joint line tenderness is present on the medial side. The anterior drawer test is negative. X-ray shows no fracture. Which of the following structure is most likely to be damaged in this patient?

A 46-year-old male has been admitted to the hospital with severe nausea and vomiting for the past two days. He also complains of fatigue and poor appetite. His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years. His medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, his temperature is 98.6F, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, his pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 16/min. Mucous membranes are dry. Lab Shows : Calcium 12.8 mg/dL Phosphate 1.9 mg/dL Albumin is 4.0 PTH is elevated Vitamin D is normal One year ago, he was diagnosed with kidney stones. A radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms and signs of hypercalcemia
Bone disease
Nepharolithaisis
Hypophosphatemia
Increased production of calcitroil
Proximal renal tubular acidosis
Hypomagnesemia
Hyperuricemia and gout
Anemia

Radiological Features of Hyperparathyroidism

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, the lateral end of the clavicle, and the symphysis pubis.
  • Loss of lamina dura (i.e., thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as a thin white line, is resorbed).

Figure: Loss of Lamina Dura
Brown Tumor: Non-aggressive lytic lesion in the second middle phalanx.
Salt and Pepper appearance of the skull

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his wife with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the neck and jaw for 1 hour. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has been a known case of hypertension for five years. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the anterior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery. After the administration of injection midazolam, fentanyl, and vecuronium, the ideal position for introducing a macintosh laryngoscope in this patient would be which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the head

questions.correct_answer: B. Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the head

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is diagnosed with vestibular schwannoma expanding into the cerebellopontine angle. A sitting craniotomy under general anesthesia is planned. The most sensitive technique to detect venous air embolism during the intraoperative period in this patient is?

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese female presents to the orthopaedics outpatient department with chief complaints of pain, stiffness, crepitus, and loss of function in the right knee from the last 8 months. She is on a pharmacological drug but has no improvement in her condition. She is planned for right total knee replacement surgery after a few days. When will be the antibiotic prophylaxis given to the patient?

A 28-year-old female, P2 L2 posted for puerperal sterilization in a family welfare camp in a hilly area. The Bain circuit was used to provide total intravenous anaesthesia with spontaneous ventilation as some major leaks in the circle system carbon dioxide absorber. Carbon dioxide elimination in this patient mainly depends on which factor?

On examination, the patient has an open wound on the parietal area of the head. The wound was washed and stitched, and the patient was sent for a brain CT scan. A 75-year-old man presented with a six-month history of global headaches, loss of balance, and a change in facial sensation. questions.text: During a primigravida's delivery in the delivery room, after successfully delivering the head, the doctor encounters difficulty in delivering the shoulders with traction. Subsequently, the doctor performs McRobert's procedure. What nerve injury may occur in the mother due to this maneuver?
questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A postpartum woman presents with a painful and engorged right breast. On examination, the breast is enlarged, and tender, and appears warmer than the surrounding skin. Ultrasound suggests generalized inflammatory changes. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: The source of the infection is usually the infant’s gastrointestinal tract

options.label: C
options.text: Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage

options.label: D
options.text: The most common offending organism is Escherichia coli.

questions.correct_answer: C. Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage

questions.text: An obstetrician, prior to vaginal delivery, plans an episiotomy in the second stage of labour. In which of these patients can a midline episiotomy be considered superior to a mediolateral episiotomy during the delivery of a fetus?
questions.correct_answer: C. Second gravida with moderate anaemia

questions.text: A senior consultant on rounds of labor room asks his residents to tell him the bishop’s score for a primigravida with severe pre-eclampsia admitted at 37 weeks. This score in this patient is used to assess which of the following?

questions.text: A 30-year-old gravida 2, para 1, female at 37 weeks gestational age, is here for a routine visit. Her first baby was a vaginal delivery of a 4.3 kg baby boy after 30 min of pushing. The present fetus is breech. A vaginal exam demonstrates that the cervix is 50% effaced and 1 to 2 cm dilated. The presenting breech is high out of the pelvis. The estimated fetal weight is about 3.2 kg. A sonogram confirms a fetus with a frank breech, normal amniotic fluid present, and the head is well flexed. Which of the following is not a correct management option in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Allow the patient to undergo a vaginal breech delivery whenever she goes into labour

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an emergency c esarean section now

options.label: C
options.text: Pinard's manoeuvre can be done for the delivery of extended legs

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule an external cephalic version in the next few days

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform an emergency c esarean section now

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, presents with labor pain at term. She has a history of previous lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). On examination, there are good contractions, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, and the interspinous diameter is 9 cm, there is Scar Dehiscence. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Forceps application in the second stage

questions.text: A 28-year-old female nearing her delivery date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and documented that the head was at +1 station. Where is the exact position of the head?

options.label: A
options.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.correct_answer: C. Just below the ischial spine

She has had a history of mitral regurgitation for 7 years which was treated with mitral valve replacement 3 years ago. Since then, she has been taking her oral anticoagulants. Which of the following fetal anomalies are most likely to be seen in this patient’s anomaly scan?

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes at 40 weeks gestation , her fundal height measures 34 cm. USG is done which shows the maximum vertical pocket of liquor < 2cm and AFI of 3 cm. Which of the following is false regarding this case scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Do induction if vaginal delivery is not contraindicated

options.label: B
options.text: During labour, cord compression is common in these patients

options.label: C
options.text: If cervix is unfavourable, immediate LSCS needs to be done

questions.correct_answer: C. If cervix is unfavourable, immediate LSCS needs to be done

questions.text: A 36-year-old Gravidity 2, parity 0 woman comes to the Gynaecological OPD for preconceptional counselling. She had previous miscarriages due to spontaneous abortions during the second trimester. The patient developed vaginal bleeding and mild suprapubic pain in both pregnancies, and both resulted in abortions. She takes folic acid and a multivitamin. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for eight years and drank alcohol occasionally but stopped both after her second pregnancy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 94/min, and her blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in assessing the cause of her previous abortions?

A 34-year-old woman with primary infertility is treated with IVF (In vitro fertilization). She becomes pregnant and attends a clinic for an ultrasound at 6 weeks of her pregnancy. Ultrasound reveals a live intrauterine pregnancy along with another gestational sac seen in the left adnexal region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of cycles of severe lower abdominal pain during her menstrual cycles for the last 2 months. The pain was not relieved with medication. The physician diagnosed her with primary dysmenorrhea after evaluation. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: No clinically significant pelvis pathology is found

options.label: B
options.text: Menorrhagia and dyspareunia are associated with this type of dysmenorrhea

options.label: D
options.text: Endometriosis & PID are important causes of primary dysmenorrhea

questions.correct_answer: A. No clinically significant pelvis pathology is found

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of sudden-onset abdominal distension , vomiting, and difficulty in breathing in a 32-year-old patient with a history of primary infertility, positive pregnancy test, and severe ascites on ultrasound, who had undergone ovulation induction and ovulation triggered with injection hCG?

questions.text: A 27-year-old presents to Gynaecology OPD with complaints of failure to conceive for the last 3 years. The patient with primary infertility is under evaluation for the cause. She has a history of regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. The pain usually starts a few days before periods and subsides on day 2. Pelvic examination reveals a fixed uterus with nodularity in the posterior fornix. Her hysterosalpingogram and husband's semen analysis are expected. Which of the following is the best tool to get a diagnosis in this case?

A 48-year-old menopausal woman presents with perineal itching. On examination, there is mild vulvar atrophy. A biopsy taken from the site is negative for malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s current condition?

A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman is referred to a gynecologic clinic by her family physician for irregular vaginal bleeding of 6 months duration. On speculum examination, a smooth and congested 5 x 2 cm elongated mass protrudes through the cervix. This was removed in the OPD with minimal twisting. Microscopic examination of the tissue shows a mass with cystic hyperplasia and a central vascular channel surrounded on three sides by epithelium. The vaginal bleeding has now stopped completely for 6 months. An ultrasonogram post-procedure is normal. What is the lesion described here?
questions.explanation:
Aspect of Endometrial Polyps Description
Definition - Endometrial polyps are small, benign growths that develop in the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium). They are made up of endometrial tissue and can vary in size, ranging from a few millimeters to several centimeters.
Incidence and Prevalence - Overview of the occurrence of endometrial polyps in the general population, as well as any specific age groups or risk factors associated with their development.
Risk Factors - Discussion of factors that may increase the risk of developing endometrial polyps, such as hormonal imbalances (e.g., excess estrogen), obesity, hypertension, and a history of certain conditions (e.g., endometrial hyperplasia or tamoxifen use).
Symptoms - Common signs and symptoms of endometrial polyps, including abnormal uterine bleeding (irregular menstrual bleeding, heavy periods, postmenopausal bleeding), pelvic pain, and possible impact on fertility.
Diagnostic Methods - Overview of diagnostic procedures used to identify endometrial polyps, such as transvaginal ultrasound, hysteroscopy, and endometrial biopsy.
Treatment Options - Description of treatment modalities for endometrial polyps, including hysteroscopic polypectomy (removal of the polyp), hormonal therapy (e.g., progestin), and, in rare cases, hysterectomy (for larger or multiple polyps or if cancer is suspected).
Histopathology and Biopsy Results - Explanation of histopathological examination of the polyp tissue after removal, which can confirm its benign nature and rule out any malignancy.
Follow-up and Surveillance - Recommendations for follow-up after polyp removal, including monitoring for recurrence, possible reevaluation of symptoms, and addressing any related concerns.

questions.text: A 54-yrs-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is discovered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma. The most appropriate intraoperative course of action is:-

options.label: A
options.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy.

options.label: C
options.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A 38 year old woman presenting with irregular heavy menstrual cycles underwent an endometrial biopsy which shows simple endometrial hyperplasia. Which of the following could have been a cause for such condition?

A 38- year woman operated on a lower segment uterine fibroid. She had an uneventful surgery. Post-operatively the urine output decreased, up to 20 ml/hr. Rapid IV fluid infusions were given with an injection of Lasix, and output increased to 70 ml/hr. The urine was clear. A patient complained of flank pain which was gradually progressing. What is the most common cause of such presentation?

A 15-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of amenorrhea. On her examination and imaging, all Mullerian derivatives are absent and she is diagnosed to have mullerian agenesis. Which one of the following is correct about this condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Wide array of uterine abnormalities

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a male baby at 37 weeks of gestation at home. After ten days, the parents brought the baby to a local hospital due to the baby's refusal to feed . The mother reveals that the baby did not receive any vaccinations until now. The pediatrician recommends polio vaccination . When was the baby supposed to get his first dose?
questions.explanation:
Vaccine Schedule
Pentavalent (DPT + Hep B + Hib), OPV 6 weeks, 10 weeks and 14 weeks
Measles and Vitamin A 9-12 months
DPT booster, OPV booster, Measles2* 16-24 months

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with sudden abdominal distension and generalized swelling for 2 days. Examination shows generalized edema, positive shifting dullness, and normal vitals. Renal function tests are normal, but urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria. What is the most likely underlying cause?

A 16-year-old boy came to the hospital with a complaint of immaturity in his voice. On examination, you made a provisional diagnosis of delayed puberty. Which of the following is the most common cause of delayed puberty?

An 8-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of multiple pathological fractures . He has had a history of deafness for 3 months. Blood picture reveals Low phosphorus and calcium levels with normal Vitamin D levels and elevated PTH. The X-rays of the pelvis and ribs are shown in the images provided.. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 9-year-old child presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of mild abdominal pain and splenomegaly. She vomits blood occasionally. The child's growth parameters are within normal limits for age, and there is no history of jaundice, pruritus, or significant alcohol consumption in the family. Laboratory investigations reveal normal liver function tests, but ultrasonography shows evidence of portal hypertension and splenomegaly . An upper GI endoscopy shows the presence of esophageal varices. A liver biopsy rules out cirrhosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old primigravid woman at 35 weeks of gestation, presents to the outpatient department for a routine antenatal visit. The pregnancy was marked by an abnormal fetal ultrasound in the second trimester, showing mild edema and hepatosplenomegaly in the fetus . Further evaluation through amniocentesis confirmed the presence of a hematological disorder. Despite optimal prenatal care, she delivers a stillborn baby with more severe generalized edema. The woman is of Mediterranean descent . Her Indian husband's genetic screening reveals he is a carrier of the disorder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis that explains the fetal outcome?

An 8-year-old child is brought by his parents to the outpatient with complaints of changes in distal fingers and nails of the hand. His parents also report that he develops bluish discolouration of the skin upon playing. He is a known case of ventricular septal defect (VSD ); surgical correction of the defect was advised, but his parents denied surgery. The patient was born full-term at 38 weeks gestation to a 24-year-old primigravida woman via normal vaginal delivery. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 98/70 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. Hand examination shows swelling of distal fingers along with nail clubbing , as shown below in the image. Cardiac examination shows a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border and a loud P2 component of the second heart sound S2 . What is the most likely cause of these findings?

A preterm neonate delivered at 32 weeks with very low birth weight develops hypoxia and respiratory distress . On examination, his lips and extremities were cyanosed and cold . He needed an emergency transfer to the NICU for neonatal resuscitation . Which of the following is considered while resuscitating the neonate?

options.label: B
options.text: Self-inflating bag should not be used without a reservoir

options.label: C
options.text: Self-inflating bag cannot deliver free-flow oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: A flow-inflating bag can deliver free-flow oxygen

questions.correct_answer: A. T-tube delivers free flow oxygen

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx for the past mont h. He is a chronic smoker and has a 15-pack-year smoking history. After further examination, the biopsy revealed glottic laryngeal carcinoma limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and no regional lymph node metastasis . Which of the following is the best treatment for this case?

A 50-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with hoarseness of voice for the last two days. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit due to a COVID-19 infection complicated by respiratory failure. He underwent endotracheal intubation and was kept on mechanical ventilation. On a laryngoscopy, he is found to have the following lesion: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic due to pain in her throat and upper neck for 2 weeks. The pain is sudden in onset, sharp radiates to the right ear, and gets aggravated on swallowing. The lateral skull x-ray of the patient is shown below: What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 30-year-old male presents to the office with complaints of headaches more during the daytime. X-ray paranasal sinuses reveal the following finding: Which of the following is not true about the lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common site is the frontal sinus

questions.correct_answer: C. Does not grow into orbit

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came to the ENT outpatient department with a complaint of dizziness while waking up from the bed. The patient has no hearing loss and ringing ears. The patient has no family history of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, or others. He had an appendectomy operation at the age of 35. The patient is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the patient developed nystagmus in the below-depicted maneuver. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?

A 38-year-old male patient presents to ENT OPD with complaints of facial weakness for 2 weeks. After investigation and examinations, the patient was diagnosed with Bell's palsy after excluding all other causes. He was on steroids for 2 weeks, but it showed no improvement. What would be the next best step in managing patient's current pathology?

A 34-year-old female presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of progressive hearing loss in her left ear over the past few months. On examination, a tuning fork test reveals bilateral conductive hearing loss, worse in the left ear. There are no signs of middle ear infection or fluid. Pure-tone audiometry confirms bilateral conductive hearing loss, and speech discrimination is normal. The Rinne test shows a positive result in the right ear and a negative result in the left ear. Weber test lateralizes to the right ear. The patient has no history of recurrent ear infections. She denies any recent trauma or exposure to loud noise. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 14-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to recurrent, profuse bleeding from the nasal cavity for 1 day . He had undergone surgery for a profuse nasal bleed 10 days ago . Also, surgery was performed for conductive deafness in the right year . The picture below shows the surgical findings of the right ear: Which of the following is the most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?

An 11-year-old boy is brought by his mother to Ophthalmology OPD with an abnormal head posture while reading and writing. He is not having any pain or other complaints. On examination, the right eye shows Entropia. The doctor suspects it to be strabismus. A refraction test is advised for further evaluation and confirmation of this condition and measurement of its angle. Which of the following drug is used before doing this test?
A patient came to the OPD with recent onset photophobia within 24 hours and a sloughing corneal ulcer. There is a greenish ulcer base. Which of the following can be the causative organism?

A 45-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department with three days history of mild irritation, watering, and localized redness in the right eye, as shown below. Her past medical history reveals that she is a known case of hypertension and takes lisinopril 5mg daily. On history, it is confirmed that she is compliant with her medication. Her blood pressure at the visit is 125/85 mmHg. The resident ophthalmologist wants to differentiate between scleritis and episcleritis. He instills 10% phenylephrine, and there is quick blanching of the vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Nodular

questions.text: A 43-year-old man was referred to your clinic for evaluation of a shallow anterior chamber in both eyes. The causes of the Shallow Anterior chamber in this patient could be all except?

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of painful swelling of the left eye and rapidly progressive loss of vision for the past 1 week. She works in a nursing home. She is otherwise vitally stable. On examination of the left eye, proptosis, complete ophthalmoplegia with eyelid swelling and decreased vision were noted. The right eye was essentially normal. Which of the following is a complication of the diagnosis of this case?

A 70-year-old man from Europe living in India presents to a physician with complaints of gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision for 1 month. He says he could earlier drive the car home by himself but cannot do so now. He is a retired navy officer. He is otherwise vitally stable. The fundus examination is given below. Which of the following is the best treatment moda lity for this the patient’s current pathology?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?

A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of a papule on his penis for the past few days . According to him, the lesions are painless and non-itchy. On examination, the lesion dimples on either side when squeezed . A central punctum is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old gravida-2, para-1 female, presents to the hospital at the 34 th week of gestation with a complaint of sudden onset of multiple painful lesions almost all over her body for the past few hours. She also reports mild fever and fatigue. She also complains of bilateral knee joint pain. questions.text: A 25-day-old female child presents with a diffuse vesiculobullous rash localized to the extremities and the trunk, following the lines of blaschko. Pitted toenails are also found.
